metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Java Booleans
Java Booleans
Very often, in programming, you will need a data type that can only have one of two values, like:
content.html: Very often, in programming, you will need a data type that can only have one of two values, like:

content.text: For this, Java has a boolean data type, which can store true or false values.
content.html: For this, Java has a boolean data type, which can store true or false values.

content.text: Boolean Values
A boolean type is declared with the boolean keyword and can only take the values true or false :
content.html: A boolean type is declared with the boolean keyword and can only take the values true or false:

content.code:
boolean
isJavaFun
=

true
;


boolean
isFishTasty
=

false
;


System
.
out
.
println
(
isJavaFun
)
;

// Outputs true


System
.
out
.
println
(
isFishTasty
)
;

// Outputs false
content.code_html:
boolean isJavaFun = true;
boolean isFishTasty = false;
System.out.println(isJavaFun);     // Outputs true
System.out.println(isFishTasty);   // Outputs false

content.text: However, it is more common to return boolean values from boolean expressions, for conditional testing (see below).
content.html: However, it is more common to return boolean values from boolean expressions, for conditional testing (see below).

content.text: Boolean Expression
A Boolean expression returns a boolean value: true or false .
content.html: A Boolean expression returns a boolean value: true or false.

content.text: This is useful to build logic, and find answers.
content.html: This is useful to build logic, and find answers.

content.text: For example, you can use a comparison operator , such as the greater than ( > ) operator, to find out if an expression (or a variable) is true or false:
content.html: For example, you can use a comparison operator, such as the greater than (>) operator, to find out if an expression (or a variable) is true or false:

content.code:
int
x
=

10
;


int
y
=

9
;


System
.
out
.
println
(
x
>
y
)
;

// returns true, because 10 is higher than 9
content.code_html:
int x = 10;
int y = 9;
System.out.println(x > y); // returns true, because 10 is higher than 9

content.text: Or even easier:

content.code:
System
.
out
.
println
(
10

>

9
)
;

// returns true, because 10 is higher than 9
content.code_html: System.out.println(10 > 9); // returns true, because 10 is higher than 9

content.text: In the examples below, we use the equal to ( == ) operator to evaluate an expression:
content.html: In the examples below, we use the equal to (==) operator to evaluate an expression:

content.code:
int
x
=

10
;


System
.
out
.
println
(
x
==

10
)
;

// returns true, because the value of x is equal to 10
content.code_html:
int x = 10;
System.out.println(x == 10); // returns true, because the value of x is equal to 10

content.code:
System
.
out
.
println
(
10

==

15
)
;

// returns false, because 10 is not equal to 15
content.code_html: System.out.println(10 == 15); // returns false, because 10 is not equal to 15

content.text: Real Life Example
Let's think of a "real life example" where we need to find out if a person is old enough to vote.
content.html: Let's think of a "real life example" where we need to find out if a person is old enough to vote.

content.text: In the example below, we use the >= comparison operator to find out if the age ( 25 ) is greater than OR equal to the voting age limit, which is set to 18 :
content.html: In the example below, we use the >= comparison operator to find out if the age (25) is greater than OR equal to the voting age limit, which is set to 18:

content.code:
int
myAge
=

25
;


int
votingAge
=

18
;


System
.
out
.
println
(
myAge
>=
votingAge
)
;
content.code_html:
int myAge = 25;
int votingAge = 18;
System.out.println(myAge >= votingAge);

content.text: Cool, right? An even better approach (since we are on a roll now), would be to wrap the code above in an if...else statement, so we can perform different actions depending on the result:
content.html: Cool, right? An even better approach (since we are on a roll now), would be to wrap the code above in an if...else statement, so we can perform different actions depending on the result:

content.code:
int
myAge
=

25
;


int
votingAge
=

18
;



if

(
myAge
>=
votingAge
)

{


System
.
out
.
println
(
"Old enough to vote!"
)
;


}

else

System

out
.
println
(
"Not old enough to vote."
)
;


}
content.code_html:
int myAge = 25;
int votingAge = 18;

if (myAge >= votingAge) {
  System.out.println("Old enough to vote!");
} else {
  System.out.println("Not old enough to vote.");
}

content.text: Booleans are the basis for all Java comparisons and conditions.
content.html: Booleans are the basis for all Java comparisons and conditions.

content.text: You will learn more about conditions ( if...else ) in the next chapter.
content.html: You will learn more about conditions (if...else) in the next chapter.

What will be the result of the following code: System.out.println(10 > 9);
